contentrichtext.text: [[File:George Pierce Baker by Pach Brothers c1886.jpg|thumb|Baker c. 1886]] '''George Pierce Baker''' (April 4, 1866 – January 6, 1935)<ref>http://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=33525823</ref> was an American educator in the field of [[drama]]. Baker graduated in the [[Harvard University]] class of 1887, and taught in the English Department at Harvard from 1888 until 1924. He started his "47 workshop" class in playwriting in 1905. He was instrumental in creating the Harvard Theatre Collection at [[Harvard University Library]]. In 1908 he began the Harvard Dramatic Club, acting as its sponsor, and in 1912 he founded Workshop 47 to provide a forum for the performance of plays developed within his English 47 class. He was elected a Fellow of the [[American Academy of Arts and Sciences]] in 1914.<ref name=AAAS>{{cite web|title=Book of Members, 1780-2010: Chapter B|url=http://www.amacad.org/publications/BookofMembers/ChapterB.pdf|publisher=American Academy of Arts and Sciences|accessdate=5 May 2011}}</ref> Unable to persuade Harvard to offer a degree in playwriting, he moved to [[Yale University]] in 1925, where he helped found the [[Yale School of Drama]]. He remained there until his retirement in 1933.<ref name="cgt">{{cite book|editor-last=Banham|editor-first = Martin|year=1998|chapter=Baker, George Pierce|title=The Cambridge Guide to Theatre|location=Cambridge|publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]]|isbn=0-521-43437-8|pages=72–73}}</ref> Baker was also selected to teach a seminar whose unconfirmed title was "Shakespeare" or "the English drama" at the [[Sorbonne]] University (Paris, France) in 1908.<ref>Archival source: CARAN, Paris. AJ/16-4750 (1907) p. 67</ref> Among those he taught in his playwriting class were [[George Abbott]], [[Philip Barry]], [[S.N. Behrman]], [[Hallie Flanagan]], [[Sidney Howard]], [[Stanley McCandless]], [[Eugene O'Neill]], [[Edward Sheldon]], [[Maurine Dallas Watkins]], and [[Thomas Wolfe]].<ref name="cgt"/> His ''Dramatic Technique'' (1919) offered a codification in English of the principles of the [[well-made play]].<ref>{{cite book | first = J L | last = Styan | title = Modern Drama in Theory and Practice I}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | editor-last = Innes | editor-first = Christopher | page = 7 | year = 2000 | title = A Sourcebook on Naturalist Theatre | location = London and New York | publisher = Routledge | isbn=0-415-15229-1}}</ref> George Pierce Baker was the father of [[George P. Baker]] who was dean of Harvard Business School.<ref>[http://oasis.lib.harvard.edu/oasis/deliver/~bak00035 Harvard Business School bio of George P.
